awd_titl_txt: Elements: Software: Autonomous, Robust, and Optimal In-Silico Experimental Design Platform for Accelerating Innovations in Materials Discovery
awd_abstract_narration:
Accelerating the development of novel materials that have desirable properties is a critical challenge as it can facilitate advances in diverse fields across science, engineering, and medicine with significant contributions to economic growth. For example, the US Materials Genome Initiative calls for cutting the time for bringing new materials from discovery to deployment by half at a fraction of the cost, by integrating experiments, computer simulations, and data analytics. However, the current prevailing practice in materials discovery relies on trial-and-error experimental campaigns and/or high-throughput screening approaches, which cannot efficiently explore the huge design space to develop materials with the targeted properties. Furthermore, measurements of material composition, structure, and properties often contain considerable errors due to technical limitations in materials synthesis and characterization, making this exploration even more challenging. This project aims to develop a software platform for robust autonomous materials discovery that can shift the current trial-and-error practice to an informatics-driven one that can potentially expedite the discovery of novel materials at substantially reduced cost and time. Throughout the project, the PI and Co-PIs will mentor students and equip them with the skills necessary to tackle interdisciplinary problems that involve materials science, computing, optimization, and artificial intelligence. Research findings in the project will be incorporated into the courses taught by the PI and Co-PIs, thereby enriching the learning experience of students.

The objective of this project is to develop an effective in-silico experimental design platform to accelerate the discovery of novel materials. The platform will be built on optimal Bayesian learning and experimental design methodologies that can translate scientific principles in materials, physics, and chemistry into predictive models, in a way that takes model and data uncertainty into account. The optimal Bayesian experimental design framework will enable the collection of smart data that can help exploring the material design space efficiently, without relying on slow and costly trial-and-error and/or high-throughput screening approaches. The developed methodologies will be integrated into MSGalaxy, a modular scientific workflow management system, resulting in an accessible, reproducible, and transparent computational platform for accelerated materials discovery that allows easy and flexible customization as well as synergistic contributions from researchers across different disciplines.

This project is supported by the Office of Advanced Cyberinfrastructure in the Directorate for Computer & Information Science & Engineering and the Division of Materials Research in the Directorate of Mathematical and Physical Sciences.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Computer and Information Science and Engineering

por.por_cntn:
Here we highlight the major research outcomes that resulted from this project.

 

1. Multi-task Gaussian Processes for Accelerated Bayesian Materials Optimization

In materials design, the common practice of ignoring the correlations between material properties, such as strength and ductility, is challenged. We propose a shift in multi-objective optimization by using Bayesian optimization and a single multi-task Gaussian Process (GP) instead of multiple independent GPs. This approach models objective functions jointly, considering their statistical correlations, to enhance design optimization by leveraging inherent relationships among material properties. Further details can be found in the following paper:

Khatamsaz, Danial, Brent Vela, and Raymundo Arróyave. "Multi-objective Bayesian alloy design using multi-task Gaussian processes." Materials Letters 351 (2023): 135067. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.matlet.2023.135067 

 

2. Bayesian optimization with active learning of design constraints

A common problem in materials design is complex multi-objective optimization  under constraints. To address this, a novel Bayesian optimization framework was developed, which efficiently navigated a vast design space while adapting to unknown constraints. This approach utilized an entropy-based decision-making process, focusing on the uncertainty in class membership probability predictions. The framework significantly improved upon traditional methods, reducing the number of required queries to identify optimal solutions. As a major outcome, the method successfully identified a set of optimal solutions that satisfied all constraints, doing so with remarkable efficiency and speed. It demonstrated a substantial reduction in the number of queries needed compared to brute force approaches and further expedited the process by implementing a batch querying policy, enhancing its applicability to a wide range of complex design problems. Further details can be found in the following paper:
Khatamsaz, D., Vela, B., Singh, P., Johnson, D.D., Allaire, D. and Arróyave, R., 2023. Bayesian optimization with active learning of design constraints using an entropy-based approach. npj Computational Materials, 9(1), p.49. https://doi.org/10.1038/s41524-023-01006-7
3. High-throughput Exploration of Multi-Dimensional Refractory Alloy Spaces
 
 In this study, a novel high-throughput alloy design framework was used to discover refractory multi-principal element alloys (MPEAs) for high-temperature applications, particularly in next-generation gas turbines. Focusing on the WMoVTaNbAl chemistry space, the framework identified 214 MoNbV-rich alloys that met key performance constraints like high yield strength and stability at temperatures above 1300°C. Through detailed density functional theory analysis, three representative alloys were further studied, with one alloy, Mo30Nb35Ta5V25W5, outperforming a database of 1,546 MPEAs. This demonstrated the framework's efficacy in navigating a complex design space to find optimal alloy candidates under multiple property constraints. Further details can be found in the following paper:

Vela, B., Acemi, C., Singh, P., Kirk, T., Trehern, W., Norris, E., Johnson, D.D., Karaman, I. and Arróyave, R., 2023. High-throughput exploration of the WMoVTaNbAl refractory multi-principal-element alloys under multiple-property constraints. Acta Materialia, 248, p.118784. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.actamat.2023.118784
 
4. Efficient and Equivariant Graph Networks for Predicting Quantum Hamiltonian
 
 Quantum tensors, such as Hamiltonian matrix, eigen wavefunctions, and eigen energies are the key physical quantities that describe materials and molecular systems and their quantum states, and almost all physical and chemical properties can be directly derived from quantum Hamiltonian and wavefunctions. Unfortunately, conventional approaches such as density functional theory (DFT) and ab initio quantum chemistry methods are computationally very expensive, limiting their use in small systems. In this work, we developed an efficient and equivariant graph network, QHNet, to predict quantum Hamiltonian, and trained and tested QHNet on quantum Hamiltonian matrices of ~130,000 molecules with high efficiency, efficacy, and flexibility. The results were published on the Proceedings of the 40th International Conference on Machine Learning: “Efficient and Equivariant Graph Networks for Predicting Quantum Hamiltonian”, PMLR 202, 40412-40424 (2023).
5. Optimal decision-making in high-throughput virtual screening pipelines
 
 Screening large pools of molecular candidates to identify those with specific design criteria or targeted properties is demanding in various science and engineering domains. While a high-throughput virtual screening (HTVS) pipeline can provide efficient means to achieving this goal, its design and operation often rely on experts’ intuition, potentially resulting in suboptimal performance. In this paper, we fill this critical gap by presenting a systematic framework that can maximize the return on computational investment (ROCI) of such HTVS campaigns. Based on various scenarios, we empirically validate the proposed framework and demonstrate its potential to accelerate scientific discoveries through optimal computational campaigns, especially in the context of virtual screening. Further details can be found in the following paper:
Hyun-Myung Woo, Xiaoning Qian, Li Tan, Shantenu Jha, Francis J. Alexander, Edward R. Dougherty, Byung-Jun Yoon, “Optimal Decision Making in High-Throughput Virtual Screening Pipelines,” Patterns, volume 4, issue 11, 100875, Nov. 10, 2023. https://doi.org/10.1016/j.patter.2023.100875

 

 


Last Modified: 12/29/2023
Modified by: Byung-Jun Yoon
